Vikas Malla wrote:
> This discussion has been exactly what I have been looking for a while. Continuing this further, I woud like to bring the question of development overheads involved.

> 1) What efforts have you guys taken in your respective organizations to reduce the programming overhead associated with writing unit tests? 

Use templates to generate testcases. Typing all that stuff in is a pita.


> 2) What are the tools you use for creation of unit tests, if any?

One of the main reasons I'm loyal to JPad pro is the fact that it 
will let me create as many class templates as needed (I have well 
over a dozen for Java alone), including the boilerplate for test 
cases (if anyone here uses JPad Pro and wants them, let me know).

Other tools don't support this very well and I don't understand why- 
I'm mainly thinking about Eclipse and IntelliJ, but often when I say 
these IDEs don't do something, I get corrected ;).

One think I don't like about the way Junit does test suites, aside 
from the effort of remembering to add a test to a suite, is that it 
drives the dependencies downward. AllTests at the top of the tree 
has to know about all the tests or testsuites below it. This seems 
to introduce cycles in Java packages and while it's not the end of 
the world or anything, it seems broken as designed to introduce 
cycles even if the payoffs for having test are substantial. It's the 
main reason I wrote a tree walker to capture and run tests; I'd 
definitely like to hear some opinions as to why I'm wrongheaded 
about this.

> 3) Do you prefer using tools for unit tests creation?

Only for blowing out the test boilerplate. I prefer to run tests 
through bash or cmd - going through an IDE can be very slow.


> 4) We use JBuilder in our development efforst. What would you advise us to go for to reduce our development overheads associated with unit tests?

Access to a bash shell and an ide that will let you generate test 
class boilerplate quickly, if JBuilder doesn't do that already.


> 5) What do you guys think of cactus?

Good project, doesn't get enough attention. I'm not sure why Jakarta 
is running all of Jelly/Maven/Cactus/Ant  (although it would be 
great to see CruiseControl/AntHill run within the Jakarta effort).

Bill de h�ra
